botanical_details.genus: Rosa can be deciduous or semi-evergreen shrubs or scrambling climbers, with usually thorny stems bearing compound pinnate leaves and solitary or clustered flowers. Flowers may be followed by showy red or purple fruits in some varieties.
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Shrub roses are large shrubs with usually thorny stems bearing large leaves and fragrant, single to double flowers in clusters in summer, and usually also in autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Thrives as a shrub in a border in full sun in rich, fertile, moist, well-drained soil. Avoid planting in sites that have previously been used for growing roses. Add mycorrhizal fungi to the roots when planting to help the plant establish quicker.
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by budding or hardwood cuttings
how_to_grow.pruning: Prune in late winter, late February to March. Cut back disproportionately long stems in line with the rest of the plant, cutting back lightly in the first year and more vigorously in later years, previous seasons growth to above an outward-facing bud about 5-10cm from the main stem, thinning out shoots as necessary and starting with diseased and damaged stems.
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids, caterpillars, glasshouse red spider mite, leafhoppers, rabbits, and rose leaf-rolling sawfly
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to rose black spot, powdery mildew and rose rust
